titleStmt.title: Two speeches: the first, spoken by the Kings most Excellent Majesty, to the commander in chiefe, that conducted him from Holdenbie towards the army. Together with a reply to His Majesties speech, by the said commander. The second, by his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, at the head of every regiment in the army, concerning the setling of a firme peace and union between the Parliament and the army, for the good of the whole kingdome. Also the souldiers resolution concerning his Majestie, and the bringing of him from Holdenby to Huntington on Friday last. Published for generall satisfaction to the whole kingdome.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 9 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Two speeches: the first, spoken by the Kings most Excellent Majesty, to the commander in chiefe, that conducted him from Holdenbie towards the army. Together with a reply to His Majesties speech, by the said commander. The second, by his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, at the head of every regiment in the army, concerning the setling of a firme peace and union between the Parliament and the army, for the good of the whole kingdome. Also the souldiers resolution concerning his Majestie, and the bringing of him from Holdenby to Huntington on Friday last. Published for generall satisfaction to the whole kingdome.
titleStmt.author: Fairfax, Thomas Fairfax, Baron, 1612-1671.
England and Wales. Sovereign (1625-1649 : Charles I)

notesStmt.note: "A misleading title; the pamphlet consists of an account of the abduction of the King from Holmby House"--Thomason Catalogue.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: TWO SPEECHES: THE FIRST, Spoken by the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, to the Commander in chiefe, that conducted him from Holdenbie towards the ARMY.
Together with a Reply to His Maje≈øties Speech, by the ≈øaid Commander.

THE SECOND, By his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, at the head of every Regiment in the Army, concerning the ≈øetling of a firme peace and union between the Parliament and the Army, for the good of the whole Kingdome.
Al≈øo the Souldiers re≈øolution concerning his Maje≈øtie, and the bringing of him from Holdenby to Huntington on Friday la≈øt.

p.hi: Publi≈øhed for generall ≈øatisfaction to the whole Kingdome.

div.p: London, Printed for F. I. Iune the 8. 1647.

div.head: A Copy of a Letter ≈øent from an Officer in the Army, to a friend of his in London.
div.p:
HAving ≈øuch a faire opportunity, to expre≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe, and to repre≈øent a ≈øubject of ≈øo great weight and concernment, to view and con≈øideration, I thought it meet and requi≈øite to acquaint you with the affaires in the≈øe parts, being (indeed) the chiefe currents of the ≈øtreame, which ebbes and flowes at this pre≈øent within the bowels of this our native Kingdome, but God grant, that the≈øe channels may receive no more additionall waters, but that the ≈ømall brooks, which now begins to force their pa≈ø≈øage into great Rivers, may be ≈øuddenly effectually ≈øtopped, that ≈øo the di≈øtraction of England may bee happily compo≈øed, and the peace and tranquility
of her poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed and langui≈øhing people, mo≈øt unanimou≈øly and faithfully ≈øetled; but becau≈øe I will not deviate too farr from my intended lines, nor detract time, with too large a Prologue, I ≈øhall briefly in≈øi≈øt upon the main branch, intimating unto you, that, which is mo≈øt con≈øiderable, e≈øpecially ≈øo much de≈øired by all ≈øorts of people viz.

On Tue≈øday la≈øt we received intelligence, that a great party of hor≈øe were di≈øcovered, betwixt Cambridge and Bedford≈øhire, & that they had a de≈øigne for the≈øe parts, which put the Inhabitants hereabouts into a great fear, not knowing their re≈øolutions and intentions: but within a ≈øhort time, this intelligence was confirmed with truth; for upon Thur≈øday morning, newes came to the Mayor of this Towne, that a party of hor≈øe lately coming from the Army, had ≈øurrounded Holdenby, with a re≈øolution to ≈øeize upon the Kings Maje≈øties per≈øon, to prevent a de≈øigne (as is ≈øaid) preiudiciall to the Kingdome; immediately after come one M. Furnace
to my hou≈øe, who affirmed, that they had entred the Hou≈øe, and repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of the King, without any oppo≈øition at all, the ≈øouldiers embracing each other, at their fir≈øt meeting, ≈øome ecchoing the≈øe words. God forbid that a ≈øword ≈øhould bee drawn in wrath, or a mu≈øquet fired in anger, again≈øt tho≈øe whom we have ≈øo often hazarded our lives withall, and with whom wee have obtained ≈øo many victories (and fight in the banner of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.

But now we heare (for certain) that they are advanced from Holdenby towards New-market in Cambridge≈øhire, there to ≈øide and joyn with the Army; as they returned, they left this Town a little wide of the right hand, ≈øounding their Trumpets, with ecchoes of tryumph: but what their de≈øigne is, time (we hope) will bring to light. God grant us a true and la≈øting peace, and prevent further blood-≈øhed.

div.head: The Re≈øolves and humble Advi≈øe of the Councel of War, convened at Bury. Satturday May 29. To your Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax Knight, Commander in chiefe of the Parliaments Forces, in relation to the Votes of Parliament, communicated to us by your Excellencie, and the de≈øires of our advice thereof.
I.
div.p: THat the ≈øaid di≈øtraction, and the jealou≈øies occa≈øioned upon the ≈øame proceeding, as wee feare, and ≈øome effects already appearing do finde, may unhappily produce dangerous di≈øturbances, and tumultuous actings among≈øt ≈øeverall parts of the Army, as they now lye di≈øper≈øed ond remote from the Head quarters, e≈øpecially among≈øt tho≈øe Regiments, who≈øe principall Officers, by neglecting or di≈ø≈øerting their ≈øouldiers in their nece≈ø≈øary concernments or ju≈øt grievances, have di≈øoblieged their ≈øouldiers, and lo≈øt their intere≈øt with them, in ≈øo much as ≈øuch Officers are forced to withdraw from their charges, and can ≈øcarce with ≈øafetie come at them, and to prevent the inconveniences or ill con≈øequences which ≈øuch di≈øturbed or tumultuous actings might produce either to the Countries where the Armie quarters or to the Kingdome.
VVe humbly advi≈øe your Excellency without delay, to draw the Army unto a clo≈øer po≈øture of quarters, till upon further ≈øatisfaction the Army may be quietly and orderly disbanded.

div.head: II.
div.p: That upon the ≈øame di≈ø≈øatisfaction and jealou≈øie we find an extream earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe, and violent propen≈øity among the Soldiers to a generall Randezvouze and wee verily beleeve, that the fir≈øt attempt to di≈øband any one Regiment, before equall ≈øatisfaction to all, and a≈ø≈øurance again≈øt tho≈øe things they have cau≈øe to feare, will occa≈øion them all to draw together, and Kandevouze of them≈øelves, as it were upon an Allarm &c.

div.head: III.
div.p: Since that cour≈øe of disbanding the Army by piece meale, before the ≈øatisfaction intended be performed equally to the whole, ≈øeems ≈øomthing ≈øtrang and unu≈øuall.

div.head: IIII.
div.p: That they would be plea≈øed to re≈øume the things voted on Tue≈øday la≈øt, as al≈øo to re≈øume the grievances of the Army, together with the things propo≈øed in the Narrative from the Officers, and to give ≈øati≈øfaction, or at lea≈øt ≈øome re≈øolution to each of them, and that they would not think it fit to put that temtation, tho≈øe ealou≈øies, and that di≈øhonour upon the Army, as to take it disbanded in ≈øcattered pieces, before ≈øatisfaction be equally given to the whole.

Friday June 4. the rendevouz of the Army was held neer Kinsford ≈øix miles from Burie, ≈øeven Regiments of Foot, and ≈øix of hor≈øe, appeared, Col. Whaleys being before di≈øpatched towards Holdenb ‚Ä¢ e (by the Generals command.) Upon this daies intelligence that our partie of hor≈øe had ≈øecured his Maje≈øtie, the Gen: gave notice of this to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, and hath ≈øignified the ≈øame to both Hou≈øes, de≈øiring to know their further plea≈øure, concerning the di≈øpo≈øing of the Kings per≈øon, al≈øo the rea≈øons of the Troopers for fetching the King from Holdenbie. He hath likewi≈øe ≈øent them the grounds inclo≈øed in a Letter from the ≈øouldiers to him≈øelf for their undertaking the ≈øame of them≈øelves: which were chiefly, that they had intimation of a de≈øigne, which they were able to make good, (of ≈øome) to ≈øurpri≈øe him. Col. Graves is di≈øcharged from that employment, and Colonell Whaley in his place. The Gen: went to every Regiment, and expre≈øt him≈øelf with much judgement and moderation, a≈ø≈øured the Souldiers that the Parliament took notice of their civill and faire demeanour, and had taken a cour≈øe for ≈øatisfying of their arrears, & doubted not but they would an≈øwer their other grievances, advi≈øed them to moderation, and to behave them≈øelves with di≈øcretion, &c.

Saturday la≈øt newes came to the Armie, that the Committee of Troopers who had ≈øecured the King, brought his Maje≈øtie Friday night to Huntington (as you had before) the King asked him that commanded in chief among the Troopers for his Commi≈ø≈øion, the partie replied, his Maj: might look about him and ≈øee his Commi≈ø≈øion, meaning 500. Troopers on hor≈øeback; ≈øaith the King, indeed your Commi≈øsion hath as faire a character in the fronte≈øpiece as ever I did ≈øee, meaning the properne≈ø≈øe and comline≈ø≈øe of the men, the Troopers being of Cap: Knights Troop, and other of Sir Robert Pies Regiment, Col. Ro≈øiters and Col. Graves.
